misconceptions.name: Implemented an entirely different problem (average acceleration instead of sum of even numbers)
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a program to compute average acceleration from initial velocity, final velocity, and time, rather than a program that reads 5 integers and computes the sum of the even ones. As a result, none of the required algorithmic components for the assigned task are present (reading 5 integers, looping over them, checking evenness, accumulating the sum).
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that the task is to compute the average acceleration given v0, v1, and t, or they reused code for a different physics problem instead of implementing the requested sum-of-evens program.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this question, the program must read exactly 5 integer values from the user, iterate over them (typically with a loop), check each number with n % 2 == 0 to determine if it is even, accumulate the sum of the even numbers in a running total, and finally print that sum.
symptoms: Prompt asks for 'v0, v1, and t' instead of 5 integers.
Program reads 3 double values rather than 5 integers.
No loop over multiple inputs.
No modulus (%) operation or even-number check.
No accumulator for sum of even numbers; instead it computes (v1 - v0) / t.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion between different assignment questions or reuse of a template for an unrelated physics problem, rather than implementing the specified sum-of-even-numbers algorithm.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully and design the solution from scratch: declare an integer sum variable, use a loop to read 5 integers, use an if (n % 2 == 0) condition to add only even numbers to sum, and then print the resulting sum.
related_concepts: Loops over fixed numbers of inputs
Conditionals with modulus for parity checking
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire structure of the program (prompt, variable names, formula) matches a standard average-acceleration exercise and has no overlap with the required sum-of-evens behavior; no elements of the intended algorithm appear.

evidence.note: This block clearly implements an average-acceleration calculation using 3 doubles, with no reading of 5 integers, no loop, no even-number check, and no sum accumulator.

misconceptions.name: Submitted code for completely different problem (Acceleration calculation)
misconceptions.description: The student submitted a complete program that calculates average acceleration based on three double inputs (v0, v1, t), rather than the required program to find the sum of five even integers. This results in the complete failure to implement looping, conditional logic, and correct input reading required by the assignment.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes the submitted code is the correct solution for Q1, or they mistakenly uploaded the solution for an unrelated problem.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires initializing a sum accumulator, using a loop structure to read 5 integers, applying a conditional check (modulo 2) to filter even numbers, and adding those numbers to the accumulator.
symptoms: Code reads 3 double inputs instead of 5 integers
Calculates acceleration formula: (v1 - v0) / t
Missing loop structure
Missing conditional check for even numbers (n % 2 == 0)
misconceptions.root_cause: Clerical error in submission or complete failure to read/understand the assignment requirements.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please review the problem statement carefully and ensure the code you submit addresses the specific requirements, including the correct number of inputs, data types, and required logical structures (loops and conditionals).
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The student's code is entirely dedicated to solving the acceleration problem, which is unrelated to the sum of even numbers problem. The divergence is absolute.

evidence.note: The prompt asks for variables for an acceleration calculation, not 5 general integers.
Reads 3 double values instead of 5 integers as required for the assignment.
Calculates acceleration, demonstrating the incorrect problem was solved.

misconceptions.name: Wrong problem implementation - physics calculation instead of sum of evens
misconceptions.description: Student submitted code that solves a completely different problem. The code calculates average acceleration using a physics formula instead of reading 5 integers and summing only even numbers. This suggests either a copy-paste error, file mix-up, or fundamental confusion about the assignment requirements.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe this assignment asks them to calculate acceleration from velocity and time values (v0, v1, t), suggesting they may have confused this assignment with a different problem or submitted the wrong file.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Q1 requires reading exactly 5 integers, iterating through them with a loop, checking each for evenness using (n % 2 == 0), accumulating a sum of only the even numbers, and printing the sum in the format 'Sum of even numbers: X'.
symptoms: Program reads only 3 values instead of 5
Program reads doubles instead of integers
Program performs physics calculation instead of even-number filtering
No loop structure present
No modulo operator or even-number checking
Output message is completely different
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely a copy-paste error or file mix-up where code from a different assignment (physics/acceleration problem) was submitted instead of the Q1 solution. Alternatively, the student may have fundamentally misread or misunderstood the assignment requirements.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Start fresh with Q1. Create a Scanner, use a for-loop from i=0 to i<5 to read 5 integers. Inside the loop, check if each number n satisfies (n % 2 == 0). If true, add it to a sum variable. After the loop, print the sum.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Extremely high confidence. The code is unambiguously solving a different problem. It reads 3 doubles for a physics acceleration calculation, not 5 integers for summing evens. Every single rubric requirement is violated. This is not a subtle misconception but a complete problem mismatch.

evidence.note: Reads 3 doubles with physics variable names (v0, v1, t) instead of 5 integers. The prompt itself reveals this is solving a different problem.
Physics acceleration formula (a = Δv/t) instead of summing even numbers. No loop, no modulo check, no accumulator.
Output message is about acceleration, not about sum of even numbers. Does not match required format.

misconceptions.name: Implemented a different problem (average acceleration) instead of summing even integers
misconceptions.description: The program computes and prints the average acceleration from physics using three double inputs (v0, v1, t) instead of reading 5 integers, selecting the even ones, summing them, and printing that sum.
misconceptions.student_belief: I can solve this question by reading v0, v1, and t as doubles, computing (v1 - v0) / t, and printing 'The average acceleration is ...'.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read exactly 5 integers from the user, check each to see if it is even (using n % 2 == 0), accumulate the sum of only the even values in a running total, and then print that sum with an appropriate message (e.g., 'Sum of even numbers: X'). It should not compute a physics formula or use v0, v1, and t.
symptoms: Prompt text asks for 'v0, v1, and t' instead of 5 integers.
Variables are named and typed as doubles for velocities and time rather than integers to be summed.
Formula used is (v1 - v0) / t with no conditional checks for even numbers.
Output message is 'The average acceleration is ...' instead of 'Sum of even numbers: ...'.
No loop or accumulator variable is used to process 5 inputs or maintain a running sum.
misconceptions.root_cause: The student appears to have written or reused code for a different assignment (average acceleration) instead of implementing the required algorithm for summing even numbers from 5 integer inputs.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully and design the algorithm specifically for it: use a loop to read 5 integers, check each with n % 2 == 0 to see if it is even, add even numbers to a sum variable, and finally print the sum. Avoid reusing code from unrelated problems, even if it compiles and runs.
related_concepts: Conditionals and modulus operator for even/odd checks
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every part of the program (prompt, variable names/types, calculation, and output text) matches a standard 'average acceleration' problem and does not implement any part of the required 'sum of even numbers from 5 integers' behavior.

evidence.note: Reads three double values (v0, v1, t) for a physics problem instead of reading 5 integers as required.

evidence.snippet:
double acceleration = (v1 - v0) / t;

System.out.println("The average acceleration is " + acceleration);
evidence.note: Computes average acceleration and prints it, with no loop, no even-number check, and no accumulation of a sum of even integers.

misconceptions.name: Complete disregard of problem requirements/Misinterpretation of Task
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a solution for calculating average acceleration (a physics formula) instead of solving the assigned task of summing even numbers from 5 inputs. This suggests either copying code from an unrelated source or a gross misunderstanding of which problem to solve.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes that the provided code fulfills the requirements of Question 1 (Sum of Even Numbers), or they submitted code for a completely different question (Acceleration Calculation) under the wrong prompt.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The requirement is to process 5 integers, check for even numbers using the modulus operator, use an accumulator variable, and iterate using a loop. The student's code does none of this.
symptoms: Code reads three double values instead of five integers.
Code calculates acceleration, not the sum of even numbers.
Code uses different variable names (v0, v1, t) unrelated to the task.
misconceptions.root_cause: The root cause is submitting a script for a different task, likely related to acceleration calculation, instead of the required summation task. This is a fundamental submission mistake.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Review the problem statement carefully and ensure the submitted code directly addresses the required task, including the correct number of inputs, data types, and core logic (looping, conditional checks, and summation).
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: High confidence as the entire functionality (input count, data types, calculation, and output) is dedicated to calculating acceleration, which is completely irrelevant to summing even numbers.

evidence.note: The inputs (three doubles v0, v1, t) and the calculation (acceleration formula) are entirely mismatched with the requirement (five integers, summing evens).

misconceptions.name: Incorrect usage of Double type for Integer input
misconceptions.description: The student reads floating-point numbers (`double`) when the problem explicitly requires reading and processing integers.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that using `double` variables is acceptable or necessary for input, even when integer input is specified, possibly confusing them with general number storage.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The problem specifies input numbers are integers. Standard practice dictates using the `int` data type and `input.nextInt()` for processing integers.
symptoms: Variables are declared as `double`.
Input methods are `input.nextDouble()`.
misconceptions.root_cause: Although this is related to the complete task misdirection, assuming the acceleration code was intended, the type choice is still incorrect for integer filtering tasks, indicating a general lack of precision in type selection.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Ensure variables are declared using the appropriate data type (e.g., `int` for integers) and use the corresponding Scanner method (e.g., `nextInt()`).
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: High confidence, as `double` is used consistently, although the core problem is task misdirection.

evidence.note: Using `double` type and `nextDouble()` when `int` and `nextInt()` are required for the task described in the prompt.

misconceptions.name: Fundamental Problem Misunderstanding - Solved Wrong Assignment
misconceptions.description: The student appears to have confused this assignment with a physics kinematics problem. Instead of reading 5 integers and summing even numbers, the code reads 3 doubles and calculates acceleration using the formula a = (v₁ - v₀)/t. This suggests either a severe misreading of the problem statement or copy-pasting code from an unrelated assignment.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes this assignment requires reading three values (v0, v1, t) and computing average acceleration using the kinematic formula a = (v₁ - v₀)/t.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: This assignment requires reading exactly 5 integers from the user, checking each one to determine if it is even (divisible by 2), accumulating the sum of only the even numbers, and printing that sum.
symptoms: Code structure completely mismatches problem requirements
Prompts for 'v0, v1, and t' instead of 5 integers
Reads 3 double values instead of 5 integer values
Performs subtraction and division instead of checking for even numbers
Output is acceleration value (wrong problem) instead of sum of evens
Cannot produce sample output '14' from sample input '3 8 2 7 4'
misconceptions.root_cause: The student did not carefully read the problem statement and either (a) confused this assignment with a different physics problem, (b) copy-pasted code from a previous assignment on kinematics, or (c) worked on the wrong assignment entirely.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Read the problem statement carefully. Start fresh: (1) Use a loop to read exactly 5 integers, (2) For each integer, use an if statement to check if num % 2 == 0, (3) If true, add to a sum variable, (4) After the loop, print the accumulated sum. Test your code with the sample input '3 8 2 7 4' to verify it outputs '14'.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Extremely high confidence. The code is objectively solving a physics acceleration problem (format: 'The average acceleration is [value]'), not the assigned 'sum of even numbers' problem. There is no ambiguity here — the student solved the wrong problem entirely.

evidence.note: Prompt asks for 'v0, v1, and t' (physics variables), not 5 integers as required by assignment.
Reads 3 double values instead of 5 integers. Wrong data type and wrong count.
Uses kinematics formula for acceleration (a = Δv/t). No loop, no modulo check, no summing of evens.
Prints acceleration instead of sum. Does not match expected output format 'Sum of even numbers: [value]'.

misconceptions.name: Incorrect Input Reading - Wrong Type and Count
misconceptions.description: The student reads only 3 values using nextDouble() instead of reading 5 integers using nextInt(). This prevents the program from accepting the required 5 integers from the user.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes nextDouble() is the correct method to use for reading input values in this context.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this problem, use nextInt() to read 5 separate integer values in a loop. nextDouble() is for floating-point numbers, which is inappropriate for this integer-processing task.
symptoms: Only 3 values can be entered (v0, v1, t)
Input is interpreted as floating-point, not integer
Cannot process the sample input correctly
misconceptions.root_cause: Confusion about which Scanner method to use; possibly copy-pasted from a different assignment that required doubles. No testing against the expected sample run.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace nextDouble() with nextInt() and wrap the read in a for loop: for(int i=0; i<5; i++) { int num = input.nextInt(); ... }
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Very high confidence. The code explicitly uses nextDouble() three times instead of nextInt() five times. This is a clear deviation from requirements.

evidence.note: Uses nextDouble() for 3 values instead of nextInt() for 5 values. Wrong method and wrong count.
